title: Why can Zoe redirect her Q while stunned?
body:
Just asking, it makes zero sense. I died because she Q'd me after I STUNNED her.

Ah, for some reason it happens during stasis too.

I guess you're totally right Pika Fox. Everybody who disagrees with you is wrong, you're objectively right and anyone who thinks otherwise is stupid. Yeah, Zoe's sleepy bubble is the weakest CC in the game I guess. That's why everybody praises how fun it is to play against.

It is objectively correct though that sleep (not drowsy, but sleep) is objectively the weakest cc.  If you take damage out of the equation, which makes sense since Fid's Q is considered strong cc while a Xerath W is not considered strong cc, sleep is just a stun that is often cut short.

The guy's initial statement was that sleep is the worst cc in the game, not sleepy trouble bubble.

Except that he's kind of right from an objective point of view.

Zoe's Sleepy trouble Bubble is the only CC in the game that can literally last 0.1 seconds without ANY CC reduction.
That being if a spell or tick of damage is applied immediately after the sleep portion of the spell is proc'd, the Hard CC portion of the spell is cleansed/broken. 

As far as CC goes it is the weakest in the game due to it's potential of having the shortest duration, making it effectively useless.

Zoe's Sleepy Trouble Bubble is not a weak spell by any means, applying Damage Amplification, Acting as a Zoning Tool and having adjustable range, but SPECIALLY as a form of crowd control it is technically the weakest in the game due to it's unique rules.

It's one of the main reasons why Ana's Sleep in Overwatch takes up such a small portion of her power budget. 

As besides it's long duration, the CC is effectively useless due to the rules surrounding it.

The bonus damage, trap, and range through terrain arent a part of sleep, theyre the benefits she specifically has on it because its inherently weak.

> Sleep is the single weakest hard CC in the game. Its delayed and breaks on damage.

completely untrue.  Being delayed makes it one of the strongest cc in the game.  If zoe's sleep was instant cc then she wouldnt have time to get a full range Q on you after she uses it and the duration of the cc would be reduced.  But because its delayed she has enough time to literally watch you, wait for it to proc, then start her q and get a max distance hit on you. Its power increases with the more team mates she has around.  If jungler comes for a gank and she lands sleep, the jungler can save his gap closer and just walk up for the gank. 

 In a team stand off where both teams are waiting for the fight to start, landing a sleep on a good target is the best engage in the game.  You know the target will be cc'd in a few seconds and have time to set up for it.  The enemy team cant break the cc unless they have {{item:3222}} so they are forced to either abandon that player or they are forced to fight. 

Think about malphite ult.  Its a great engage tool but by the time your team mates react to it and close in, the knockup is over. So having an engage that is (1) safe/long range (2) has a short cooldown and (3) is delayed but just as effective makes her cc one of the best. 

 Dont forget the target is slowed to a crawl so they cant run to far.  It also stays on the ground for an eternity (very unlike most hard cc).

Pretty sure it is intentional, and there are more reasons to do it for her.

First, as said, it is almost all her damage, minimum 50% of her damage.  Second, it is a double cast ability, meaning that if it was stopped by that, there would be a massive window to prevent her from using her main source of damage.  Third it has no cc attached, so it isn't going to prevent the enemy from taking advantage of her being stunned unless they would die from that very attack (which she initially cast before the stun).

I can't think of a single other ability that fits those criteria.  Also if they did make her Q interruptible, they'd probably buff her passive and/or W to make up for her lost skirmish potential (just saying this to let you know what the result of a "fix" would likely be).
